description._content: From 'Street Life in London', 1877, by John Thomson and Adolphe Smith ...While reducing the general death-rate, our recent sanitary legislation has called into existence a class of men who must of necessity be daily exposed to the gravest dangers. To the list of men who, by reason of their avocations, constantly face death to save us from peril, we must add the public disinfectors. For the full story, and other photographs and commentaries, follow this link and click through to the PDF file at the bottom of the description archives.lse.ac.uk/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&i...

note._content: Mr Dickinson the inspector of nuisances for the Parish or Union of St George's, Hanover Square
note.author: 48511485@N06

note._content: The disinfectors wearing overalls which are burnt after use.
note.author: 48511485@N06

note._content: hermetically sealed handcart for the transport of infected material eg bedclothes of smallpox victims
note.author: 48511485@N06

note._content: yard adjoining the Vestry, close by Ebury Bridge.
